sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russia begins to evacuate Kherson as an attack by Ukraine to recapture the city appears imminent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Support grows in Finland for the construction of partial border fencing along its frontier with Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The Russian authorities have begun a mass evacuation of civilians from Kherson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The thought a Ukrainian push to recapture the city is imminent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And it's a key moment for both sides.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Winter is approaching and their positions will soon remain mostly frozen until the spring.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The authorities say these evacuations are voluntary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But in many cases, the only routes out are to Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Organized efforts to relocate residents to the other bank of the Dnipro River are underway in Kherson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: A ferry service is now available to take people from the port of Kherson to Oleshki and Kholat Pristan, where a temporary accommodation point has opened.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Rescuers will guide the direction of the trip.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It will be chosen based on the desire of the person themselves." Back in February, Kherson was one of the first major cities to fall to the Russians. But on Wednesday, in a response to a series of military setbacks, President Putin announced the imposition of martial law in the four territories he's annexed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Before joining the Russian Federation, the Donetsk Popular Republic, Luhansk Popular Republic and the region of Kherson and Zaporizhia were de facto living under martial law. So now it just has to be formalized according to Russian legislation. That's why I signed a decree introducing martial law and those four subjects of the Russian Federation. I will immediately send it to the Federation Council for approval. Whilst parts of Ukraine, such as here in recently liberated Kupyansk, begin to recover from occupation, others remain under almost constant attack.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And across Ukraine, energy and water supplies are being threatened as strikes reach far into the country and damage key facilities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians in more than a thousand settlements did not have power following Russia's attacks on critical infrastructure, according to Ukraine's Ministry of Energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The head of the European Commission called these strikes, quote, the acts of pure terror that amount to war crimes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The head of Krivoy Rih's military administration, Oleksandr Vilko, said Russia launched rocket fire overnight on an energy facility, causing serious destruction in his region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian forces also shot down 13 drones over Mykolaiv overnight, according to the region's governor Vitaly Kim.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Zaporizhia was also attacked overnight with Russia firing on critical infrastructure in a village, according to the regional governor, Oleksandr Starukh.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Energy infrastructure has been hit in Vinnytsia region on Wednesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The Institute for the Study of War says Russian forces have directed dozens of Iranian-made drones against civilian targets in Ukraine since mid-September, prioritizing creating psychological terror effects on Ukrainian civilians rather than achieving tangible battlefield effects.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: In northeast of Ukraine, Russian troops conducted a limited ground attack in northern Kharkiv region, seemingly suggesting that Russian forces may retain territorial aspirations in this area despite massive losses during the recent Ukrainian counter-offensive operations across the entire front line in Kherson region, targeting Russian ground lines of communication and ammunition depots in central Kherson region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Russian authorities are struggling to cope with their reduced logistics capacity through Crimea following the attack on the Kerch Strait Bridge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Is this your last Prime Minister's questions?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Is it time to resign? Aren't you leading a coalition of chaos?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Embattled UK leader Liz Truss faced difficult questions even before she arrived at Parliament on Wednesday to face her first Prime Minister's question since making a dramatic U-turn on tax cuts. Once in the chamber, she wasn't able to avoid answering. I've got the list here. 45p tax cut, gone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Corporation tax cut, gone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: 20p tax cut, gone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Two-year energy freeze, gone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Tax-free shopping, gone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Economic credibility, gone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And her supposed best friend, the former Chancellor, he's gone as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They're all gone. So why is she still here?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Mr Speaker, I am a fighter and not a quitter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I have acted in the national interest to make sure that we have economic stability.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Liz Truss's plans to grow the economy by lowering taxes fell apart after they caused chaos on the financial markets, resulting in the sacking of her newly appointed Chancellor, Kweisi Kwarteng.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But her critics say the policies he announced were hers and even some of her own backbenchers think her position as Prime Minister is untenable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: British Prime Minister Liz Truss has said she's a fighter and not a quitter at Prime Minister's questions at Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Truss is currently polling with the lowest approval rating of a Prime Minister ever.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: She was forced to U-turn on her promises to cut tax for high earners after sparking market turmoil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Despite trying to correct the economic plans, mortgage payers are still facing higher rates because of her moves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, with me now is Adam Schwartz, a political commentator.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Adam, thanks so much for taking the time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This, of course, was Liz Truss's big moment to convince that she was back in control.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Did she manage it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, I think certainly she performed better than some had expected after the very dire news conference they held just a few days ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So I think expectations were particularly low. So I don't think it was disastrous, but I don't think it was a particularly great performance, really.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: However, I don't think it really changes the kind of fundamentals of the situation that she's in. At the moment, she's a leader that really is without credibility, without authority, and without any kind of democratic legitimacy. And I think, at the moment, most governments midway through their terms are simply planning in know in terms of months or years. But actually this is a government that's trying to cling on really on a day to day moment by moment basis. So I think she's probably done enough in terms of trying trying to buy herself a little bit of time. Hopefully you know in terms of trying to get to October the 31st for the the fiscal statement but certainly I don't think it really has changed the fundamental situation that she's facing which is a very premature end to a premiership only 43 days into taking the job it did appear in Prime Minister's questions that there was another u-turn as well when it came to pensions and she could have potentially undermined her Chancellor there who of course she needs Jeremy Hunt's support and the support of her cabinet so do you think that could be problematic for her? I think from a sort of technical point of view obviously you know one side or the other will come out as supreme and obviously you know she is reliant upon the support of Jeremy Hunt in terms of trying to survive and maintain a cohesive cabinet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But I think really what the major significance of it is that it really shows that this is not a government that has sort of a very cohesive approach. And even though it's trying to sort of turn a new leaf in terms of trying to set a new policy trajectory, actually, it's still having problems in trying to manage messages and also trying to manage just basic policy going forward. So I think it's possible that she was simply trying to assert authority following a few days where authority seemed to sap away from her towards her new chancellor. But I think from a political perspective, it doesn't look very good. But also from a sort of economic and fiscal perspective potentially this may be an issue going forward having to raise pensions by 10 when already after the u-turns the government remains 38 billion pounds uh you know in in sort of a shortfall so i think certainly from a political perspective it's difficult but also from an economic perspective and a fiscal perspective it looks very difficult for her as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Finland has moved a step closer to approving the construction of a fence along parts of its border with Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Prime Minister Sanna Marin says there is a growing cross-party support, which has gained traction since Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Helsinki is concerned over a possible large-scale and illegal cross-border migration. Finland shares with Russia the longest border of any EU member and wants the main section of the proposed fence on its south-east where most border traffic takes place.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We want to ensure that we have sufficient support for our border guard force to carry out effective and appropriate border control.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: In addition, we need to be prepared for any disruptive situations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Between 130 and 260 kilometers of partial fencing is proposed along Finland's 1,300 kilometer border with Russia. Many Russians have fled their country due to Moscow's call for a partial mobilization of more troops.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The cost is estimated to run into the hundreds of millions of euros and construction would take place in the next three to four years.
